Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support: International Workshop on Big Data in Life Sciences, Atlanta, GA, September 9, 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Big Data problems and challenges have become a reality in modern day computational biology and bioinformatics. The objective of this proposal is to request funds that will be used to support students and postdoctoral researchers from U.S. institutions to travel to the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) International Workshop on Big Data in Life Sciences (BigLS), to be held on September 9, 2015 in Atlanta, GA, in conjunction with the 2015 ACM Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology and Health Informatics (ACM-BCB). This travel award will help orient students and postdoctoral researchers in the emerging area of Big Data analytics in life sciences. It will create a unique opportunity for supported students to present their on-going work, network with experts and peers in the field, receive mentoring, while contributing to the workshop's technical program. It will help to prepare the future generation scientific workforce to meet the challenges of this critical area of life sciences.

Funds will be used to support up to 10 students and postdoctoral researchers, working in areas at the intersection of Big Data and life sciences. Recipients of the support will be selected via a widely advertised competitive process involving the submission of a travel grant application, and review by the workshop's organizational committee. Preference will be given to women and underrepresented minority groups, first-generation college students, and undergraduate researchers. The workshop will feature peer-reviewed papers and invited talks on five key research themes that underline Big Data research in life sciences: i) scalable algorithms and techniques for Big Data analytics in molecular biology, ii) statistical and integrative approaches to Big Data biology and informatics, iii) high performance computing methods and software for Big Data biology, iv) scientific workflows and platforms for Big Data in life sciences, v) software and hardware solutions for managing Big Data in biomedical informatics. This year's special emphasis theme is on scientific workflows for Big Data analytics, including workflows design, optimization, management and execution in HPC and cloud environments.

CCF    1550931         

Student Travel Support: International Workshop on Big Data in Life Sciences, Atlanta, GA, September 9, 2015

PI: Ananth Kalyanaraman, Washington State University

 

BigLS’15 Workshop Organizers:

Ananth Kalyanaraman, Washington State University

Jaroslaw Zola, SUNY Buffalo

http://www.cse.buffalo.edu/~jzola/BigLS/BigLS2015/

 

The 2015 ACM International Workshop on Big Data in Life Sciences (abbreviated as BigLS’15) was held in conjunction with the annual with the annual ACM Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology and Health Informatics (ACM-BCB) conference (http://acm-bcb.bme.gatech.edu/2015/index.html). The workshop was held on September 9, 2015 in Atlanta, GA. The main conference was held on dates September 10-12 at the same location.

 

Intellectual Merits: not applicable (since this is a student travel award solely focused on broader impact)

 

Broader Impacts:

 

Travel Awardees: The travel awards were selected after an initial open call for student scholarship proposals and a screening process based on the merits of the applicant and their potential to benefit from attending the workshop. Every effort was made to reach out to minority/underrepresented groups (particularly women applicants). By the submission deadline, we received a total of 12 student applicants from across the U.S.

 

After careful consideration, the $10,000 travel award from NSF was used to support 7 graduate students from U.S. universities. This included 3 females and 4 male students, all of them graduate students at various stages of their doctoral program. The basic statistics of the supported students are as follows (names excluded):

 

  1. PhD student, Mathematics, Colorado State University (female)
  2. PhD student, Computer Science, Purdue University (male)
  3. PhD student, Computer Science, University of Buffalo (male)
  4. PhD student, Computer Science, Purdue University (male)
  5. PhD student, Computer Science, University of Tennessee, Knoxville (male)
  6. PhD student, Epidemiology, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill (female)
  7. PhD student, Computer Science, University of Georgia (female)

 

The exact amount of support varied between $1,300 and $1,500 per awardee based on their expenses. The eligible expenses for the travel award included the conference registration fees, travel air fare and hotel lodging expenses. In all cases, the awarded amount covered only part of the above expenses, and the remaining costs were covered by the students’ respective advisors or institutions. The travel awards were managed as reimbursements through the Washington State University’s Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture’s Travel Office.

 

Student activities: All students who were supported by this award were required to participate in the following activities organized by the workshop organizers:

i)                   All of them attended the entire BigLS workshop. Most of them also attended part or whole of the main ACM-BCB conference as well. The students were encouraged to ask questions during the Q&A and also interact with the speakers offline. The BigLS’15 program included 1 keynote talk, 3 invited talks and 2 peer-reviewed paper talks. The keynote and invited talks were given by highly accomplished researchers in the area of computational biology, bioinformatics, and biomedicine.

ii)                 At the BigLS workshop, all students presented a research poster in a poster session (3:15pm-5pm).

iii)               All students were attached to an academic mentor prior to the workshop date, and on the day of the workshop, the students met and interacted with their respective mentors during the poster session and for the remaining part of the conference. The mentors identified were all researchers (including invited speakers at the workshop and other faculty attending the BCB conference). The goal of the mentoring program was to establish a channel of communication between the students (who are early career scientists) and accomplished researchers in the field, so that they get advice and input on various topics ranging from technical aspects of the field to career advices such as how to perform job search or conduct interdisciplinary collaboration. The feedback we received from the students on this mentoring component was overwhelmingly positive.

For more information about the Advance Program of the BigLS’15 workshop, please visit:  http://www.cse.buffalo.edu/~jzola/BigLS/BigLS2015/BigLS-2015-Program.html
